summary.para: The LinkableComponentStatus enumerates the possible statuses that a linkable component can be in. The state diagram showing the possible statuses and the transitions from one status to another can be found in the documentation for OpenMI 2.0 on .
They are also mentioned in the documentation of the various methods of the .

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Created
member.summary: The linkable component instance has just been Created. This status must and will be followed by .

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Initializing
member.summary: The linkable component is initializing itself. This status will end in a status change to or .

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Initialized
member.summary: The linkable component has succesfully initialized itself. The connections between its inputs/outputs and those of other components can be established.

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Validating
member.summary: After links between the component's inputs/outputs and those of other components have been established, the component is validating whether its required input will be available when it updates itself, and whether indeed it will be able to provide the required output during this update. This Validating status will end in a status change to or .

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Valid
member.summary: The component is in a valid state. When updating itself its required input will be available, and it it will be able to provide the required output.

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.WaitingForData
member.summary: The component wants to update itself, but is not yet able to perform the actual computation, because it is still waiting for input data from other components.

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Invalid
member.summary: The component is in an invalid state. When updating itself not all required input will be available, and/or it will not be able to provide the required output. After the user has modified the connections between the component's inputs/outputs and those of other components, the state can be entered again.

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Preparing
member.summary: The component is preparing itself for the first GetValues() call. This Preparing state will end in a status change to or .

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Updating
member.summary: The component is updating itself. It has received all required input data from other components, and is now performing the actual computation. This Updating state will end in a status change to , or .

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Updated
member.summary: The component has succesfully updated itself.

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Done
member.summary: The last update process that the component performed was the final one. A next call to the Update method will leave the component's internal state unchanged.

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Finishing
member.summary: The ILinkableComponent was requested to perform the actions to be performed before it will either be disposed or re-intialized again. Typical actions would be writing the final result files, close all open files, free memory, etc. When all required actions have been performed, the status switches to when re-initialization is possible. The status switches to when the component is to be disposed.

member.name: F:OpenMI.Standard2.LinkableComponentStatus.Finished
member.summary: The ILinkableComponent has successfully performed its finalization actions. Re-initialization of the component instance is not possible and should not be attempted. Instead the instance should be disposed, e.g. through the garbage collection mechanism.

members.member:
The component was requisted to perform the actions to be perform before it will either be disposed or re-initialized again. Typical actions would be writing the final result files, close all open files, free memory, etcetera. When all required actions have been performed, the status switches back to if the component supports being re-initialized. If it cannot be re-initialized, it can be released from memory.
The linkable component has failed initialize itself, failed to prepare itself for computation, or failed to complete its update process.

summary.para: Defines a method to get the Id of an OpenMI entity. The extends the , and therefore has, next to the id, a caption and a description.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.IDescribable
member.summary:
Provides descriptive information on an OpenMI entity.
An entity that is describable has a caption (title or heading) and a description. These are not to be used for identification (see ).

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IDescribable.Caption
member.summary: Caption string (not to be used as an id)

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IDescribable.Description
member.summary: Additional descriptive information about the entity.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IIdentifiable.Id
member.summary: Returns the Id as a String. The Id must be unique within its context but does not need to be globally unique. E.g. the id of an input exchange item must be unique in the list of inputs of a ILinkableComponent, but a similar Id might be used by an exchange item of another ILinkableComponent.

summary.para: Time interface based on a Modified Julian Date (number and fraction of days since 00:00 November 17, 1858).
The ITime interface supports a time stamp as well as a time interval. A time stamp will have its set to 0, while a time interval will have a positive value.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITime.StampAsModifiedJulianDay
member.summary: Time stamp as a modified julian day value.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITime.DurationInDays
member.summary: Duration in days. O if time is a time stamp.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.ExchangeItemChangeEventArgs

The ExchangeItemChangeEventArgs contains the information that will be passed when the fires the ExchangeItemValueChanged event.
Sending exchange item events is optional, so it should not be used as a mechanism to build critical functionality upon.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.IElementSet
member.summary:
Data exchange between components in OpenMI is nearly always related to one or more elements in a space, either geo-referenced or not. An element set in OpenMI can be a list of 2D or 3D spatial elements or, as a special case, a list of ID based (non spatial) elements. The latter is supported to allow the exchange of arbitrary data that is not related to space in any way. Possible element types are defined in .
An IElementSet is composed of an ordered list of elements having a common type. The geometry of each element is described by an ordered list of vertices. For 3D elements (i.e. polyhedrons) the shape can be queried by face. When the element set is geo-referenced co-ordinates (X,Y,Z,M) can be obtained for each vertex of an element.
A geo-referenced element set needs to have a valid SpatialReferenceSystemWkt property set in the . This is a string that specifies the OGC Well-Known Text representation of the spatial reference. An empty string indicates that there in no spatial reference, which is only valid if the ElementType is ID_BASED.
While an IElementSet can be used to query the geometric description of a model schematization, it does not necessarily provide all topological knowledge on inter-element connections.
Although most models encapsulate static element sets, some advanced models might contain dynamic elements (e.g. waves). A version number has been introduced to enable tracking of element set changes over time. If the version changes, the element set might need to be queried again during the computation process.

remarks.para: For ElementSets of type ElementType.IdBased the SpatialReferenceSystemWkt property an empty string.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ISpatialDefinition
member.summary:
Data in components in OpenMI is often related to spatial coordinates, either geo-referenced or not. The is the general spatial construct that all other spatial constructions extend from.
The currently most noticable extending interfaces is the , which in previous versions of the standard was the only spatial construction, and which all other spatial constructions had to be wrapped into, whereas in the current version the is an extension of the .
Although most models encapsulate data with a static spatial definition, some advanced models might contain dynamic spatial definitions (e.g. waves, moving grids). The number has been introduced to enable tracking of spatial changes over time. If the version changes, the spatial definition might need to be queried again during the computation process.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ISpatialDefinition.SpatialReferenceSystemWkt

summary.para: The SpatialReferenceSystemWkt speficies the OGC Well-Known Text representation of the spatial reference system to be used in association with the coordinates in the .
For the list of WKT strings see .

member.example:
For all spatial axis a spatial reference can be defined in a form:
PROJCS["Mercator Spheric", GEOGCS["WGS84based_GCS", DATUM["WGS84based_Datum", SPHEROID["WGS84based_Sphere", 6378137, 0], TOWGS84[0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0]], PRIMEM["Greenwich", 0, AUTHORITY["EPSG", "8901"]], UNIT["degree", 0.0174532925199433, AUTHORITY["EPSG", "9102"]], AXIS["E", EAST], AXIS["N", NORTH]], PROJECTION["Mercator"], PARAMETER["False_Easting", 0], PARAMETER["False_Northing", 0], PARAMETER["Central_Meridian", 0], PARAMETER["Latitude_of_origin", 0], UNIT["metre", 1, AUTHORITY["EPSG", "9001"]], AXIS["East", EAST], AXIS["North", NORTH]]

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ISpatialDefinition.ElementCount
member.summary: Number of data elements in the spatial axis.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ISpatialDefinition.Version
member.summary:
The current version number for the spatial axis.
The version must be incremented if anything inside the spatial axis is changed, or if an entirely new spatial axis is provided.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.IElementSet.GetElementIndex(OpenMI.Standard2.IIdentifiable)
member.summary: Index of element with id in the elementset. Indexes start from zero. There are not restrictions to how elements are ordered.
member.param: Identification string for the element for which the element index is requested.
member.returns: Index of the element with the specified id. If no element in the ElementSet has the specified elementId, -1 must be returned.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.IElementSet.GetElementId(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns Id of the '-th' element in the ElementSet. Indexes start from zero. If the ElementType of the ElementSet is not IdBased, a null or an empty string may be returned.
member.param: The element index for which the element Caption is requested. If the element index is outside the range [0, number of elements -1], an exception must be thrown.
member.returns: The id of the element with the specified index. If the index is out of range, an exception must be thrown.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.IElementSet.GetVertexCount(System.Int32)

summary.para: Number of vertices for the element specified by the elementIndex.
If the GetVertexCount()method is invoked for element sets of type , an exception must be thrown.

param.name: elementIndex
param.para: The element index for the element for which the number of vertices is requested.
If the element index is outside the range [0, number of elements -1], an exception must be thrown.

member.returns: Number of vertices in element defined by the elementIndex.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.IElementSet.GetFaceCount(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the number of faces in a 3D element. For 2D elements this returns 0.

param.name: elementIndex
param.para: If the element index is outside the range [0, number of elements -1], an exception must be thrown.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.IElementSet.GetFaceVertexIndices(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gives an array with the vertex indices for a face.
member.param: Element index.
Face index.
member.returns: The vertex indices for this face.
member.remarks: The vertex indices for a face must be locally numbered for the element (containing numbers in the range [0;(elementIndex)-1]).

Vertex index in the element with index elementIndex.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.IQuality
member.summary:
Qualitative data described items in terms of some quality or categorization that may be 'informal' or may use relatively ill-defined characteristics such as warmth and flavour. However, qualitative data can include well-defined aspects such as gender, nationality or commodity type. OpenMI defines the IQuality interface for working with qualitative data.
An IQuality describes qualitative data, where a value is specified as one category within a number of predefined (possible) categories. These categories can be ordered or not.
For qualitative data the IValueSet exchanged between ILinkableComponents contains one of the possible ICategory instances per element in the ElementSet involved.
Examples:
Colors: red, green, blue
Land use: nature, recreation, industry, infrastructure
Rating: worse, same, better

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IQuality.Categories
member.summary: Returns a list of the possible allowed for this IQuality. If the quality is not ordered the list contains the ICategory's in an unspecified order. When it is ordered the list contains the ICategory's in the same sequence.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IQuality.IsOrdered
member.summary: Checks if the IQuality is defined by an ordered set of ICategory or not.

member.summary: Gets the owner of the exchange item. For an output exchange item this is the component responsible for providing the content of the output item. It is possible for an exchange item to have no owner, in this case the method will return null.

member.name: E:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseExchangeItem.ItemChanged
member.summary: The ItemChanged event is fired when the content of an exchange item has changed. This might be because its ValueDefinition has changed, its TimeSet has changed, its ElementSet has changed, its Values have changed, or any permutation of these properties.

summary.para: An input item that can accept values for an .

member.summary: Time information on the values that are available in an output exchange item, or required by an input exchange item

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITimeSpaceValueSet
member.summary: The represents an ordered two-dimensional list of values. The first dimension stands for the times for which values are available, whereas in the second dimension each value belongs to precisely one element in the corresponding (that was specified when asking for the values). In other words, the i-th value in that dimension of the value set corresponds to the i-th element in the IElementSet.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseValueSet
member.summary:
The represents a general multi-dimensional set of values. Each value is of type
The size of each dimension can vary, depending on the indices provided, e.g. in a 2D matrix each row can have different lengths. Example, assuming the data is stored as a double[][] matrix, then matrix[1].Length need not equal matrix[2].Length.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseValueSet.GetIndexCount(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Returns the length (max index count) of the dimension specified by the given indices. To get the size of the first dimension, use a zero-length integer array as input argument. Length of indices must be a least one smaller than the
member.param: indices of the dimension to get the length of

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseValueSet.GetValue(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Returns the value object specified by the given array of indices. The length of the array of indices is N, so that the index for each dimension is specified. Otherwise an IllegalArgumentException must be thrown.
member.param: indices index value for each dimension
member.returns: the value object for the given indices

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseValueSet.SetValue(System.Int32[],System.Object)
member.summary: Set the value object specified by the given array of indices. The length of the array of indices is N, so that the index for each dimension is specified. Otherwise an IllegalArgumentException must be thrown.
member.param: indices index value for each dimension
value the value object for the given indices

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseValueSet.ValueType

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseValueSet.NumberOfIndices
member.summary: Returns the number of possible indices (dimensions) for the value set.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITimeSpaceAdaptedOutput
member.summary:
An adds one or more data operations on top of an output item. It is in itself an . The adaptedOutput extends an output item with functionality as spatial interpolation, temporal interpolation, unit conversion etc.
ITimeSpaceAdaptedOutput instances are created by means of an .
The IAdaptedOutput is based on the adaptor design pattern. It adapts an IOutput or another IAdaptedOutput to make it suitable for new use or purpose. The object being adapted is typically called the "adaptee". The IAdaptedOutput replaces the DataOperation that was used in OpenMI 1.x.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseAdaptedOutput
member.summary:
An adds one or more data operations on top of an output item. It is in itself an . The adaptedOutput extends an output item with functionality as spatial interpolation, temporal interpolation, unit conversion etc.
instances are created by means of an .
The is based on the adaptor design pattern. It adapts an or another to make it suitable for new use or purpose. The object being adapted is typically called the "adaptee". The replaces the DataOperation that was used in OpenMI Standard version 1.x.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseOutput
member.summary:
An output exchange item that can deliver values from an .
If an output does not provide the data in the way a consumer would like to have it the output can be adapted by an , which can transform the data according to the consumer's wishes. E.g. by performing interpolation in time, spatial aggregation, etc.).

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseOutput.AddConsumer(OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseInput)
member.summary:
Add a consumer to this output item. Every input item that wants to call the GetValues() method, needs to add itself as a consumer first.
If a consumer is added that can not be handled, or that is incompatible with the already added consumers, an exception will be thrown.
The AddConsumer method must and will automatically set the consumer's Provider (see ) consumer that has to be added

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseOutput.RemoveConsumer(OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseInput)
member.summary: Remove a consumer. If an input item is not interested any longer in calling the GetValues method, it should remove itself by calling RemoveConsumer. consumer that has to be removed

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseOutput.AddAdaptedOutput(OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseAdaptedOutput)
member.summary:
Add a to this output item. Every adaptedOutput that uses data from this output item, needs to add itself as a consumer first.
If a adaptedOutput is added that can not be handled, or that is incompatible with the already added adaptedOutputs, an exception will be thrown. consumer that has to be added

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseOutput.RemoveAdaptedOutput(OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseAdaptedOutput)
member.summary: Remove a . If a adaptedOutput is not interested any longer in this output item data, it should remove itself by calling RemoveConsumer. consumer that has to be removed

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseOutput.Consumers
member.summary:
Input items that will consume the values, by calling the GetValues() method. Every input item that will call this method, needs to call the AddConsumer method first. If the input item is not interested any longer in calling the GetValues, it should remove itself by calling the RemoveConsumer method.
The list is readonly. Add and remove from the list by using and .
member.remarks: Please be aware that the "unadulterated" values in the output item, provided by the read only Values property, may be called anyway, even if there are no values available.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseOutput.AdaptedOutputs
member.summary:
The adaptedOutputs that have this current output item as Adaptee. As soon as the output item's values have been updated, for each adaptedOutput its method must be called.
The list is readonly. Add and remov from the list by using and .

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseOutput.Values
member.summary: The exchange item's values

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseAdaptedOutput.Initialize
member.summary:
Let the adapted output initialize itself, based on the current values specified by the arguments. Only after initialize is called the refresh method might be called.
A component must invoke the method of all its adapted outputs at the end of the component's Prepare phase. In case of stacked adapted outputs, the adaptee must be initialized first.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseAdaptedOutput.Refresh
member.summary:
Request the adapted output to refresh itself. This method will be called by the adaptee, when it has been refreshed/updated. In the implementation of the refresh method the adapted output should update its contents according to the changes in the adaptee.
After updating itself the adapted output must call refresh on all its adapted outputs, so the chain of outputs refreshes itself.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseAdaptedOutput.Arguments
member.summary:
Arguments needed to let the adapted output do its work. An unmodifiable list of the (modifiable) arguments should be returned that can be used to get info on the arguments and to modify argument values. Validation of changes is done when they occur (e.g. using notifications).
Unmodifiable list of IArgument for the adapted output

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseAdaptedOutput.Adaptee
member.summary: Output item that this adaptedOutput extracts content from. In the adapter design pattern, it is the item being adapted.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITimeSpaceOutput
member.summary:
An output exchange item that can deliver values from a time / space dependent ILinkableComponent. The output is a combination of an , an , and an . This combination specifies which type of data can be provided where and when by the ILinkableComponent.
If an output does not provide the data in the way a consumer would like to have it the output can be adapted by an , which can transform the data according to the consumer's wishes. E.g. by performing interpolation in time, spatial aggregation, etc.).
If a output item does provide the data in the way a consumer would lik to have it the output item can be decorated by an , which can transform the data according to the consumer's wishes (e.g. by performing interpolation in time, spatial interpolation etc.).

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITimeSpaceOutput.GetValues(OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseExchangeItem)
member.summary: Overridden version of the method. now returns an , instead of an .

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITimeSpaceOutput.Values
member.summary: The exchange item's values, as a specialized

summary.para: A set of time stamps or time intervals, used to indicate where an output item has values and can provide values, and where an input item does or may require values.
The defines whether the set contains stamps or intervals.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITimeSet.Times
member.summary:
Time stamps or spans as available in the values of an output item, or as required by an input item.
Specific values:
TimeSet.Times.Count == 0, in case of output: time dependent item, but no values available yet or required yet
TimeSet.Times.Count == 0, in case of in: time dependent item, but currently no values required

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITimeSet.HasDurations
member.summary: True if the have durations, i.e. are time intervals. In this case, a duration value greater then zero is expected for every ITime in the list.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITimeSet.OffsetFromUtcInHours
member.summary: Time zone offset from UTC, expressed in the number of hours. Since some of the world's time zones differ half an hour from their neighbours the value is specified as a double.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.TimeSpace.ITimeSet.TimeHorizon
member.summary:
The time horizon defines for an input item for what time span it may require values. This means the providers of this input can assume that the input item never goes back further in time than the time horizon's begin time, TimeHorizon.StampAsModifiedJulianDay. Also, it will never go further ahead than the time horizon's end time, TimeHorizon.StampAsModifiedJulianDay+TimeHorizon.DurationInDays. For an output item, and thus for an adapted output item, the time horizon indicates in what time span the item can provide values.
Specific values:
TimeHorizon.StampAsModifiedJulianDay == Double.NegativeInfinity: far back in time
TimeHorizon.Duration == Double.PositiveInfinity: far in the future

summary.para: An providing exchange items of type time-space.
See for details
The IBaseLinkableComponent is the key interface in the OpenMI standard.
OpenMI-compliance definition (The compliancy refers to a set of basic interfaces as well as to optional extension interfaces, e.g. for time and space dependent components):
1) An OpenMI-compliant component must implement the IBaseLinkableComponent interface according to specifications provided as comments in the OpenMI.Standard2 source code.

2) An OpenMI compliant component can also comply to one ore more extensions, by implementing the IBaseLinkableComponent interface and the extension interfaces which it wishes to comply to, according to the specifications provided as comments in the OpenMI.Standard2 source code.
3) An OpenMI-compliant component including its extensions must, when compiled, reference the OpenMI.Standard2*.dlls/jars, which are compiled and and released by the OpenMI Association.
4) An OpenMI-compliant component must be associated with an XML file, the so called OMI file, which complies to (can be validated with) the LinkableComponent.xsd schema.

5) An OpenMI-compliant component must be associated with an XML file, the so called compliancy info file, which complies to (can be validated with) the OpenMICompliancyInfo.xsd schema. This file must be submitted to the OpenMI Association.

6) The OpenMI Association provides two additional interfaces that OpenMI-compliant components may or may not implement: the interface and the interface. However, if these interfaces are implemented, each method and property must be implemented according to the comments given in the OpenMI.Standard2 source code.
7) The OpenMI Associations downloadable standard zip file provides the only recognized version of source files, XML schemas and assembly files.
Initializes the LinkableComponent.
The method will and must be invoked before any other method or property in the ILinkableComponent interface is invoked or accessed, except for the property.
Immediatly after the method is invoked, it changes the linkable component's Status to .
When the method is executed and an error occurs, the Status of the component will change to , and an exception will be thrown. If the component initializes succesfully, the status is changed to .
When the method has been finished and the Status is , the properties Id, Caption, Description, , , have been set, and the method can be called.
It is only required that the method can be invoked once. If the method is invoked more than once and the LinkableComponent cannot handle this; an exception must be thrown.
REMARKS:

The method will typically populate the component based on the values specified in its arguments, which can be retrieved with getArguments. Settings can be used to read input files, allocate memory, and organize input and output exchange items.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseLinkableComponent.Validate

summary.para: Validates the populated instance of the LinkableComponent

This method must be accessible after the method has been invoked and until the method has been invoked. If this property is accessed before the method has been invoked or after the method has been invoked and the LinkableComponent cannot handle this an exception must be thrown.
The method will and must be invoked after the various provider/consumer relations between this component's exchange items and the exchange items of other components present in the composition.
Immediatly after the method is invoked, it changes the linkable component's Status to .
When the Validate method has finished, the Status of the component has changed to either or .

member.returns: Returns null or an array of strings of length null if there are no messages at all. If there are messages while the components Status is , the messages are purely informative. If there are messages while the components Status is , at least one of the messages indicates a fatal error.

summary.para: Prepares the IBaseLinkableComponent for calls to the method

Before Prepare is called, the component are not required to honor any type of action that retrieves values from the component. After Prepare is called, the component must be ready for providing values.

This method must be accessible after the method has been invoked and until the method has been invoked. If this property is accessed before the method has been invoked or after the method has been invoked and the LinkableComponent cannot handle this an exception must be thrown.
Immediatly after the method is invoked, it changes the linkable component's Status to .
When the method has finished, the Status of the component has changed to either or .
It is only required that the Prepare( ) method can be invoked once. If the Prepare method is invoked more that once and the LinkableComponent cannot handle this an exception must be thrown.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseLinkableComponent.Update(OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseOutput[])
member.summary:
This method is called to let the component update itself, thus reaching its next state.
Immediately after the method is invoked, it changes the linkable component's Status to .
The type of actions a component takes during the method depends on the type of component. A numerical model that progresses in time will typically compute a time step. A database whould typically look at the consumers of its output items, and perform one or more queries to be able to provide the values that the consumers require. A GIS system would typically re-evaluate the values in a grid coverage, so that its output output items can provide up-to-date values.
If the Update method is performed succesfully, the component sets its state to , unless after this Update action the component is at the end of its computation, in which case it will be set its State to .
If during the Update method a problem arises, the component sets its state to , and throws an exception.
member.param: This optional parameter lets the caller specify the specific output items that should be updated. If it is omitted or if the length is 0, the component will at least update its output items that have consumers, or all its output items, depending on the component's implementation.

summary.para: This method is and must be invoked as the last of any methods in the ILinkableComponent interface.

This method must be accessible after the method has been invoked. If this method is invoked before the method has been invoked and the LinkableComponent cannot handled this, an exception must be thrown.
Immediatly after the method is invoked, it changes the linkable component's Status to . Once the finishing is completed, the component changes its status to if it can not be restarted, or if it can.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseLinkableComponent.Arguments
member.summary:
Arguments needed to let the component do its work. An unmodifiable list of (modifiable) arguments must be returned that is to be used to get information about the arguments and to set argument values. Validation of changes can be done either when they occur (e.g. using notifications) or when the initialize method is called. Initialize will always be called before any call to the update method of the IBaseLinkableComponent.
This property must be available as soon is the linkable component instance is created. Arguments describes the arguments that can be set before the Initialize() method is called.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseLinkableComponent.Status
member.summary:
Defines current status of the linkable component. See for the possible values.
The first Status that a component sets is , as soon after it has been created. In this Status, is the only property that may be accessed.

member.name: E:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseLinkableComponent.StatusChanged
member.summary: The StatusChanged event is fired when Status of the component changes. See for the possible states, and see the documentation, e.g. the OpenMI Standard 2 Specification, for possible state changes.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseLinkableComponent.Inputs
member.summary: The list of input items for which a component can recieve values.

remarks.para: This property must be accessible after the method has been invoked and until the method has been invoked. If this property is accessed before the method has been invoked or after the method has been invoked and the LinkableComponent cannot handle this an exception must be thrown.

This method basically returns references to items. There is no guarantee that the list of objects is not altered by other components after it has been returned. It is the responsibility of the LinkableComponent to make sure that such possible alterations do not subsequently corrupt the LinkableComponent.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseLinkableComponent.Outputs
member.summary: The list of output items for which a component can produce results.

remarks.para: This property must be accessible after the method has been invoked and until the method has been invoked. If this property is accessed before the method has been invoked or after the method has been invoked and the LinkableComponent cannot handle this an exception must be thrown.

The list only contains the core IBaseOutput of the component, not the IBaseAdaptedOutput derived from each IBaseOutput (etc.). To get a complete list of outputs traverse the chain of IBaseAdaptedOutput that start with the IOutputs returned in the list.

This method basically returns references to items. There is no guarantee that the list of objects is not altered by other components after it has been returned. It is the responsibility of the LinkableComponent to make sure that such possible alterations do not subsequently corrupt the LinkableComponent.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IBaseLinkableComponent.AdaptedOutputFactories
member.summary:
Get a list of , each allowing to create item for making outputs fit to inputs in case they do not already do so.
Factories can be added to and removed from the list so that third-party factories and IBaseAdaptedOutput classes can be introduced.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.IByteStateConverter
member.summary: This interface is an optional complement to the interface. Both are extensions to , meant to provide state management. It defines methods for converting a state into a byte stream and reading in a state from a byte stream. This facilitates external modules, e.g. a GUI or an operational control system, to save a model's state somewhere as persistent state.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IByteStateConverter.ConvertToByteArray(OpenMI.Standard2.IIdentifiable)
member.summary: Converts the state with the into a byte stream.
member.param: id of the state.
member.returns: The state identified by as an array of bytes.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IByteStateConverter.ConvertFromByteArray(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Creates a state from a byte stream and returns the identifier of this state. The state does not become the current state of the . For state management the interface is to be used.
member.param: State as a byte stream.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.IManageState
member.summary: Optional interface to be implemented by components in addition to the interface. It provides additional methods for handling component state so it can be saved, restored and cleared. It can be left completely to the component to handle persistence of state or it can also implement and provide ways for state to be converted to and from an array of bytes. A third-party could then handle the saving and loading of state data.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IManageState.KeepCurrentState
member.summary: Store the linkable component's current State

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IManageState.RestoreState(OpenMI.Standard2.IIdentifiable)
member.summary: Restores the state identified by the parameter stateID. If the state identifier identified by stateID is not known by the linkable component an IllegalArgumentException exception should be trown.
member.param: Identifier of the state to be restored.
member.remark: The method must throw an ArgumentException if an unknown is specified.

member.name: M:OpenMI.Standard2.IManageState.ClearState(OpenMI.Standard2.IIdentifiable)
member.summary: Clears a state from the linkable component's memory. If the state identifier identified by stateID is not known by the linkable component an IllegalArgumentException exception should be thrown.
member.param: Identifier of the state to be cleared.
member.remark: The method must throw an ArgumentException if an unknown is specified.

summary.para: The IArgument interface is used to set the arguments of a and the arguments of an

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IArgument.ValueType
member.summary: The type of the value of the argument, E.g. a integral type like string, integer or double, or a non integral type, such as a time series object.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IArgument.IsOptional
member.summary: Specifies whether the argument is optional or not. If the Values property returns null and IsOptional == false, a value has to be set before the argument can be used.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IArgument.IsReadOnly
member.summary: Defines whether the Values property may be edited. This is used to let a or an present the actual value of an argument that can not be changed by the user, but is needed to determine the values of other arguments or is informative in any other way.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IArgument.Value
member.summary:
The current value of the argument. If no value has been set yet, a default value is returned.
If null is returned, this means that the default value is null.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IArgument.DefaultValue
member.summary: The default value of the argument.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IArgument.PossibleValues
member.summary: List of possible allowed values for this argument. If for integral types or component specific types all possible values are allowed, null is returned. A list with length 0 indicates that there is indeed a limitation on the possible values, but that currently no values are possible. Effectively this means that the values will not and cannot be set.

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.IArgument.ValueAsString
member.summary: The argument's value, represented as a string. If ValueType indicates that the argument's value is not of the type string, the ValueAsString function offers the possibility to treat it as a string, e.g. to let the GUI persist the value in the composition file.

member.name: T:OpenMI.Standard2.ICategory
member.summary:
The ICategory describes one item of a possible categorization. It is used by the interface for describing qualitative data.
For qualitative data the exchanged between s contains one of the possible ICategory instances per data element.
A category defines one "class" within a "set of classes".

member.name: P:OpenMI.Standard2.ICategory.Value
member.summary: Value for this category.
